text: well um the process I think is unique to
the subject if you if you were to look
at the body of my work uh it moves
around from one subject to another so it
could be mining itself where we remove
remove uh The Ore from the land or it
could be tailings which is a byproduct
of mining could be quaries it could be
refineries it could be um a dam in China
or now could be uh um you know the
cities being built in China uh and each
one of those things I approach first as
as conceptually like why why that why
why that and not that you know like how
do I go from a general idea to the
specific place in which I'm going to
make a photograph of and there's a whole
bunch of criteria I might put to it is
it visual is it interesting you know uh
is there a sense of scale within it is
there um is there any particular reason
you know um why I photograph that
intersection in LA and not another one
well yes it's one of the biggest in the
world and it was where the freeway
freeway began so there are other
components that I'll I'll use to to
determine uh where my target is that I'm
going to go and try and photograph but
then once I understand like for instance
when I did the refinery series uh I
never try to photograph a Refinery but I
went in there with my first with a
handheld camera and just shot sh it just
walked through and responded guttery to
the thing I just whatever caught my
attention I'm not using 4x5 I'm not
slowing down I'm walking through I'm
responding then I go
back and start working with a 4x5 using
those kinds of uh touch points as a
reference uh and and then start to you
know photograph and then i' try all
kinds of films to see how that subject
and the like conditions in which which
that subject uh you know would it be sun
would it be a Cloudy a partly cloudy day
you know evening or Sunrise how does it
how does that subject react under the
different uh uh times of day and light
what films do the colors the pallet of
the thing I'm photographing what film
best um responds to it so I'd shoot all
the different films that I that were
available on the market I'd make prints
I'd try out different papers with it
until I say aha here's a combination
here's the film I'm going to use this is
the my position to the subject this is
where in that subject I'm going to
photograph this is the paper I'm going
to use to print it on now I've
established my form I've established my
working approach and then I'd start
going back and I'd go back maybe five
six seven times in that one first
Refinery then I developed a kind of a
language that I felt I was comfortable
with and then I said okay now I'm going
to try and find some other refineries
that might bring other perspectives to
it or different times that that they
were built um different things things
that they were refining and then I would
add to that body of work until I felt
okay I I've I've I feel I've exhausted
this I've somehow taken this visually as
far as I can go I don't have anything
else that I feel I need to say about
this and then I might close a chapter to
that project and go on to that and that
might take two or three years before I
by the time I get access into it shoot
it and some things like the refineries
